results.headline: A Man Who Spewed His Seed Finds the Son Who’s No Prize Crop
results.summary_short: Rachael Harris stars in “Natural Selection,” Robbie Pickering’s debut feature about a woman who sets out to find her husband’s son.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Natural Selection

results.headline: Up From the Basement, Slacker Metaphysics
results.summary_short: In this comedy by the Duplass brothers, Jeff (Jason Segel), a weed-puffing 30-year-old slacker, rises from his basement lair for what begins as a simple errand.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jeff Who Lives At Home

results.headline: Vengeance Comes With a Catch
results.summary_short: “Seeking Justice” portrays a New Orleans man (Nicolas Cage) who makes a deal for retribution against his wife’s assailant.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Seeking Justice

results.headline: In French Occupation, a Broader Resistance
results.summary_short: An Algerian immigrant in Paris overcomes his ambivalence to help fight Nazi occupation in “Free Men,” a film directed by Ismael Ferroukhi.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Free Men

results.headline: Substitute Teacher, Just Trying to Do Good by His Pupils
results.summary_short: “Detachment,” from Tony Kaye, is a close-up on high school life and dysfunctional families.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Detachment

results.headline: Going Back to High School, Undercover With Badges and Baggage
results.summary_short: The movie “21 Jump Street” is full of the usual boy-comedy stuff, and though no conceptual ground is broken, the whole mess is silly, spirited and, yes, smart enough to work.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 21 Jump Street

results.headline: An Artist at Work, Looking and Judging
results.summary_short: This film by Corinna Belz is an exploration of Mr. Richter’s working process.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gerhard Richter Painting

results.headline: Exploring an Impetuous, and Tentative, Office Romance
results.summary_short: The French actress Audrey Tautou stars as a workaholic widow pursuing an unexpected relationship.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Delicacy

results.headline: An Impotent Outlaw in the American West
results.summary_short: In “Good for Nothing,” an Englishwoman in America is taken hostage by an unnamed man who can’t achieve his predatory designs.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Good For Nothing

results.headline: Here Comes the Bride’s Understudy
results.summary_short: A celebrity couple recruit “The Decoy Bride” to throw off a persistent photographer.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Decoy Bride

results.headline: The Stuff of Life in Bitter Marginalia
results.summary_short: A father and son are Talmudic scholars and academic competitors in Joseph Cedar’s “Footnote,” in which petty rivalries encompass a larger gravitas.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Footnote

results.headline: Immersed in Anger and Smothered by Loneliness
results.summary_short: In Nina Menkes’s “Dissolution,” a morose Israeli Jew living in a predominantly Arab section of Tel Aviv spends his days aimlessly.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dissolution

results.headline: The Things They Did for Love (and Attention)
results.summary_short: In “The Ballad of Genesis and Lady Jaye” the director Marie Losier profiles an English musician and his wife, taking a lighthearted look at the strange things they did for love.
results.display_title: The Ballad of Genesis and Lady Jaye

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Ballad of Genesis and Lady Jaye

results.headline: Anarchist Percussionists and a Belly as an Instrument
results.summary_short: “Sound of Noise,” about a gang of anarchist percussionists and a detective named Amadeus, turns into a character study mixed with an outlandish crime procedural.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sound of Noise

results.headline: Haunted Home Looks Great by Lantern Light
results.summary_short: “Silent House,” starring Elizabeth Olsen, is a horror movie whose gimmicks are more interesting than its frights.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Silent House

results.headline: Theater Competition Rescues Students From Their Own Dramas
results.summary_short: A state competition for California high school students is the subject of Alex Rotaru’s documentary “Shakespeare High.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shakespeare High

results.headline: Creative Sheik Wants to Stock Desert With Fish
results.summary_short: The director Lasse Hallstrom (“Chocolat”) has transformed “Salmon Fishing in the Yemen,” based on an absurdist political satire, into a whimsical romantic comedy.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Salmon Fishing in the Yemen

results.headline: The Wild, Wild West of a Certain Red Planet
results.summary_short: “John Carter” stars Taylor Kitsch as a Civil War veteran transported from the Old West to another internecine battle — on Mars, of all places.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of John Carter

results.headline: Mastering Fish as an Edible Art Medium
results.summary_short: In David Gelb’s documentary “Jiro Dreams of Sushi,” the master behind the Tokyo restaurant Sukiyabashi Jiro demonstrates his long-practiced art.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jiro Dreams of Sushi

results.headline: Let’s Have a Baby and Look for Love Later
results.summary_short: “Friends With Kids” is a romantic comedy that wonders whether sexual attraction can survive childbirth.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Friends With Kids
